title: Great Britain men's Olympic football team
text:
The Great Britain men's Olympic football team is the men's <a href="Association%20football">football</a> team that represents the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> (<a href="Great%20Britain%20and%20Northern%20Ireland">Great Britain and Northern Ireland</a>) at the <a href="Summer%20Olympic%20Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> (where it competes as <a href="Great%20Britain%20at%20the%20Olympics">Great Britain</a>, currently branded <a href="Team%20GB">Team GB</a>). The team is organised by the English <a href="The%20Football%20Association">Football Association</a> (FA) as the men's footballing representative of the <a href="British%20Olympic%20Association">British Olympic Association</a>. The team only competes in the Olympic Games. In other <a href="association%20football">international football</a> tournaments, the <a href="Home%20Nations">Home Nations</a> of the United Kingdom (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland) are represented by their own national teams, a situation which pre-dated the establishment of a GB team.
The team first competed at the FA organised tournament for the <a href="1908%20Summer%20Olympics">1908 Olympics</a> held in London, which was the first games that featured representative teams using players selected nationally (prior games in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201900%20Summer%20Olympics">1900</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201904%20Summer%20Olympics">1904</a> used club teams). This team and the two that followed in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201912%20Summer%20Olympics">1912</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201920%20Summer%20Olympics">1920</a> featured only English <a href="Amateur%20sports">amateur</a> players, and is seen by some as merely an extension of the <a href="England%20national%20amateur%20football%20team">English amateur team</a>, set up in 1906 in response to the rise of the professional game. In this period the team won the gold medal at the 1908 and 1912 tournaments, although exited at Round 1 in 1920. A dispute between the FA and FIFA over the inclusion of professionals saw the FA withdraw from Olympic football in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201924%20Summer%20Olympics">1924</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics">1928</a>, and saw no football at the Olympics at all in 1932.
After the creation of the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>, it was agreed that Olympic football would become exclusively amateur, leading to the team competing again in the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936</a> Games, this time incorporating players from other Home Nations. After the break caused by World War II, the team then competed in every games from <a href="Football%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948</a> until <a href="Football%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972</a>, albeit failing to qualify for the main tournament after <a href="Football%20at%20the%201960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960</a>. In this period the team's best performance was fourth place in 1948 at the second Games hosted in London, under manager <a href="Matt%20Busby">Matt Busby</a>.
After the FA abolished the distinction between amateur and professional players in 1974, it stopped entering a team. By the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992</a> Games teams could use professionals, but were restricted to players under 23 years old, with only three over-age players allowed per squad. Despite this change, Great Britain did not enter a football team again until London won the right to host the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Games</a>. The FA organised the team, with <a href="Stuart%20Pearce">Stuart Pearce</a> appointed manager. A <a href="Great%20Britain%20women%27s%20Olympic%20football%20team">Great Britain women's team</a> also competed at the 2012 and <a href="Football%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020</a> Games.
History.
Origins.
The FA was formed in London 1863, when thirteen teams met to draw up a shared <a href="Laws%20of%20the%20Game%20%28association%20football%29">rule list</a> for football, in order to facilitate matches between clubs. The question of the geographical remit of this organisation does not appear to have been asked, with the FA being formed before the rise of international football. The <a href="England%20v%20Scotland%20representative%20matches%20%281870%E2%80%931872%29">first football matches between national teams</a> were arranged by the FA, who invited English and Scottish players to form representative teams. The Scottish teams were made up almost entirely of Scottish residents in England and in order to encourage more Scottish based players to compete, an organisation in Scotland was sought to form the Scottish team. For the <a href="1872%20Scotland%20v%20England%20football%20match">1872 game between Scotland and England</a> in Glasgow, <a href="Queen%27s%20Park%20F.C.">Queen's Park Football Club</a> took on this role, and this game is now recognised as the first international match. Within a year, the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20Association">Scottish Football Association</a> (SFA) was founded to facilitate these matches, and to organise football in Scotland more broadly. The third national football association, the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Wales">Football Association of Wales</a> was founded in 1876 and a fourth, the <a href="Irish%20Football%20Association">Irish Football Association</a>, (IFA), was founded in 1880.
The practice of playing internationals between the four <a href="countries%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a> (also known as the <a href="home%20nations">home nations</a>) was thus developed before football associations were developed elsewhere in the world and, no 'United Kingdom football association' was ever formed. Outside of the UK, the first national associations were formed in 1889 (in <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a> and the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>), and these also began to pick their own national teams. When football was included at the <a href="1900%20Olympic%20Games">1900 Olympics</a>, however, many nations were still struggling to raise a team, and so club teams entered instead. <a href="Upton%20Park%20F.C.">Upton Park</a> represented the UK, winning the gold medal.
1908–1936.
For the <a href="1908%20Olympic%20Games">1908 Olympic Games</a> in <a href="London">London</a>, the FA persuaded the IOC to include an official football tournament, which they organised. A team, made up entirely of English players, was entered. Some sources continue to refer to this team as the <a href="England%20national%20amateur%20football%20team">England national amateur football team</a>, whilst others still simply label all participations as "Great Britain". Although the team competed as the United Kingdom and are listed as such, the official match report refers to "the English team". The Scottish Football Association passed a resolution to "protest against one National body in the British Isles being termed the United Kingdom, or playing as such without the consent of the other three National Associations". The resolution was read at the next meeting of the <a href="International%20Football%20Association%20Board">International Football Association Board</a>. In response, "[t]he Football Association representatives explained that this was the name given by the authorities, and that so far as the Football Association was concerned they had nothing to do with the matter. The Scottish Association were satisfied with this answer."
At the 1908 Olympics, "Great Britain and Ireland" won all three of their matches, defeating <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> and <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> in the first two rounds. They met <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a> in the final, defeating them 2–0 with goals from <a href="Vivian%20Woodward">Vivian Woodward</a> and <a href="Frederick%20Chapman%20%28footballer%29">Frederick Chapman</a>.
The team repeated this success at the <a href="1912%20Summer%20Olympics">1912 Games</a>. Again, Britain won all three matches and defeated Denmark in the final, this time 4–2. Woodward, who scored in the previous final, was captain for this tournament.
At the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201920%20Summer%20Olympics">1920 Summer Games</a>, Britain lost in the first round in a surprise defeat to <a href="Norway%20national%20football%20team">Norway</a>. Britain had played only <a href="amateur">amateur</a> players, while other nations selected their team from all available players. The tournament formed part of a rift which developed between the FA, who wanted the Olympics to remain an amateur only competition, and FIFA, who were keen on having a full football world championship. This resulted in the FA leaving FIFA, as well as withdrawing from the <a href="1924%20Summer%20Olympics">1924</a> and <a href="1928%20Summer%20Olympics">1928</a> football tournaments. Eventually, however, an agreement was reached in which the Olympic football tournament would be for amateur players only, with the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> created to include all players, professional and amateur.
There was no football tournament at the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 games</a>, so Britain's return to Olympic football came at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a>. Great Britain were defeated in the quarter-finals, losing 5–4 to <a href="Poland%20national%20football%20team">Poland</a>.
1948–1970.
Following the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, Great Britain competed in all Olympic football tournaments from <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948</a> through to <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972</a>. The <a href="Football%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 tournament</a>, which was hosted in <a href="London">London</a>, was the team's most successful. By this time, it was recognised that Britain's amateur players were not of the same quality as they had been in earlier years, due to the rise of the professional game. By contrast, teams in nations which had not yet developed professional leagues were able to field their strongest sides. Manager <a href="Matt%20Busby">Matt Busby</a> trained a squad made up of players from all of the '<a href="home%20nations">home nations</a>', and Britain progressed to the semi-final with wins over <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">the Netherlands</a> and <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a>. Having lost the semi-final to <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20football%20team">Yugoslavia</a>, Britain once again faced Denmark. This time, however, they were defeated 5–3 and missed out on a bronze medal. <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a> hosted Great Britain's final two matches, though they also played at <a href="Craven%20Cottage">Craven Cottage</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20Stadium">Highbury</a>.
After 1948, Great Britain were never a significant threat at the Olympics again. They were eliminated after losing their opening match to <a href="Luxembourg%20national%20football%20team">Luxembourg</a> in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952</a>, and qualified for the <a href="Association%20football%20at%20the%201956%20Summer%20Olympics">1956</a> only after other teams withdrew, before being beaten by <a href="Bulgaria%20national%20football%20team">Bulgaria</a> in the quarter-finals. Their final appearance at an Olympic Games came in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960</a>. The squad was again selected from all of the home nations, with matches between the national amateur sides being used to choose a best 19. Great Britain were eliminated in the first round, losing one, drawing one and winning one of their three matches. After that Great Britain failed to qualify for the next three Olympics, with their final match being a 5–0 qualifying round defeat by <a href="Bulgaria%20national%20football%20team">Bulgaria</a> in 1971 following a 1–0 victory at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a> against the same team.
In 1974, the Football Association stopped recognising a distinction between <a href="professional%20sports">professionals</a> and <a href="amateur%20sports">amateurs</a>, with all player subsequently registered simply as 'players', whether paid or unpaid. This ended the existence of the <a href="England%20national%20amateur%20football%20team">England amateur team</a>, which had always been the basis for the British Olympic team. As such, the FA stopped entering a football team into Olympic competition.
1972–2008.
For the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a>, professional footballers were allowed to compete at the Olympics for the first time. Initially, European and South American teams were banned from playing players who had competed in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>, but from the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992 Summer Olympics</a> eligibility for all nations was restricted to players aged under 23, except that three players of any age are allowed in the squad.
Since 1992, the <a href="UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">UEFA European Under-21 Championship</a> has acted as the qualifying tournament for the UEFA nations, which each of the <a href="Home%20Nations">Home Nations</a> enter. On three occasions, teams from Great Britain have finished in the qualifying positions:
In March 1996, the <a href="Scottish%20National%20Party">Scottish National Party</a> proposed that the Scotland U21s should compete in the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Olympics football tournament</a>, having finished fourth in the <a href="1996%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">1996 UEFA European Under-21 Championship</a>. Scotland would have qualified for the Summer Olympics football tournament twice in succession, having also finished fourth in the <a href="1992%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">1992 edition</a>. The <a href="Scottish%20Football%20Association">Scottish Football Association</a> (SFA) opposed the idea of the Scotland team being sent to the Olympics as they would have had to participate as Great Britain, which the SFA considered would have jeopardised the independent status of Scottish national teams.
The <a href="British%20Olympic%20Association">British Olympic Association</a> initially refused to rule out the possibility of entry for the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Games</a>, England would have qualified for the 2008 Olympics by reaching the semi-finals of the <a href="2007%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">2007 Under–21 Championship</a>, but a team was not entered. <a href="Italy%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Italy</a> took their vacated place by winning a play-off match against <a href="Portugal%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Portugal</a>. The <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">England women's team</a> also qualified for the 2008 Olympics, through their performance in the <a href="2007%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2007 World Cup</a>, but they were denied a place at the Olympics because the other three Home Nations refused to give their consent.
Reformation for London 2012.
Due to the success of the <a href="London%202012%20Olympic%20bid">London 2012 Olympic bid</a>, the United Kingdom gained the right to enter a team in the football tournament as host nation. The <a href="British%20Olympic%20Association">British Olympic Association</a> (BOA) stated it would enter a football team, but the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20Association">Scottish Football Association</a> (SFA) refused even to attend meetings at which the <a href="Home%20Nations">Home Nations</a> were to discuss the possibility and the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Wales">Football Association of Wales</a> (FAW) withdrew from the negotiations. The <a href="Irish%20Football%20Association">Irish Football Association</a> (representing Northern Ireland) stated in October 2007 that they would not take part in a unified team, leaving <a href="the%20Football%20Association">the Football Association</a> (England) as the only association willing to take part. The SFA's opposition to the plans were rooted primarily in the fear that the Home Nations would be forced to field a combined team in all competitions. This would mean the loss of the special status of the Home Nations, established under FIFA's constitution.
Various fans, politicians and sports-people all gave their opinions with regards to the creation of a team. A 2005 <a href="opinion%20poll">opinion poll</a> published by the BOA claimed that a majority of Scots supported the creation of a British team for the 2012 Olympics. A joint statement issued by the official fan clubs of all four Home Nations voiced their opposition to the plan. Various prominent <a href="politician">politician</a>s also offered their opinion as to whether there should be a British team in the 2012 Olympics. <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Gordon%20Brown">Gordon Brown</a> stated during the 2008 Olympics that he wanted a British team and would work towards that happening, although he acknowledged that it could affect the autonomy of the Home Nations. <a href="First%20Minister%20of%20Scotland">First Minister of Scotland</a> <a href="Alex%20Salmond">Alex Salmond</a> then stated his opposition to a British team, arguing that Brown must be "seriously out of touch with Scotland" to support it.
<a href="President%20of%20FIFA">FIFA President</a> <a href="Sepp%20Blatter">Sepp Blatter</a> initially assured each of the British Associations that their status would not be affected by fielding a combined team in 2012. The SFA refused to change its position, arguing that Blatter's personal opinion and permission might not matter once he has left office, and that they did not wish to jeopardise their status. Blatter seemed to change his view in March 2008, when he stated that "they should enter only a team composed of players from England" and he suggested that the independent status of the four British associations could be harmed by a unified team. <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> chief executive <a href="David%20Taylor%20%28Scottish%20football%29">David Taylor</a>, a former chief executive of the SFA, said in August 2008 that a British Olympic team would threaten the existence of the individual home nations. Taylor also said that the unique status of the Home Nations had come under attack before from other FIFA members, and that it was "difficult to see what guarantees could be given" to protect that status. At a conference held in conjunction with the <a href="2008%20FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">2008 FIFA Club World Cup</a> in Japan, the prospect of a UK team for the 2012 Olympics was discussed by the FIFA Executive Committee, who gave their approval.
From the world of sport, <a href="2011%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20400%20metres%20hurdles">world 400 m hurdles champion</a> <a href="Dai%20Greene">Dai Greene</a> said that he felt that there should not be an Olympic football tournament because the Olympics is not the pinnacle of that sport. He also expressed fears that coverage of the football team would overshadow interest in the other competitors. <a href="Sebastian%20Coe">Sebastian Coe</a>, the director of the 2012 Olympics, regularly spoke out in support of the team.
A compromise was eventually reached between the four associations, whereby a squad of English players only would represent the United Kingdom. The football associations of Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales sent a joint letter to FIFA stating that they would not participate, but that they would not object to England participating alone. This agreement was challenged by the BOA, who wanted to select players from all four countries and claimed it would be potentially discriminatory to only select English players. <a href="Jim%20Boyce">Jim Boyce</a> stated that there is no legal restriction on players being selected by the BOA and the SFA admitted that it would have no legal grounds to prevent Scottish players from participating. It was then confirmed that the FA intended to select players from outside England. Eligible non-English players such as <a href="Gareth%20Bale">Gareth Bale</a> and <a href="Aaron%20Ramsey">Aaron Ramsey</a> expressed their desire to play in the squad, having posed for a photo-shoot wearing the <a href="replica">replica</a> shirts of the team.
Pre-tournament preparations.
The FA announced in October 2011 that <a href="Stuart%20Pearce">Stuart Pearce</a> would be the manager. After this announcement, Pearce drew up an initial long-list of players who he wanted to consider for the squad, and wrote to all of these players to inform them of his choice. Pearce said that players who did not want to be included would be able to inform him of their wishes at that stage. It was stated in December 2011 that none of the players selected for the <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> squad for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">2012 UEFA European Championships</a> would be selected, in order to avoid player fatigue. In January 2012, it was revealed that 191 players had been contacted, with 7 declining to be considered for the team. A further cut was announced in April 2012, with the shortlist of eligible players reduced to around 80. The final pre-tournament cut occurred in early June, when a squad of 35 players was submitted to FIFA.
Great Britain were placed in group A for the Olympic tournament prior to the draw. The draw was held on 24 April 2012 and added <a href="Uruguay%20Olympic%20football%20team">Uruguay</a>, <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="Senegal%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Senegal</a> to Great Britain's group. The final 18-man squad for the Olympic Games was announced on 2 July 2012. A pre-tournament training camp was held in <a href="Marbella">Marbella</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. This included a training match against <a href="Mexico%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Mexico</a>, which Mexico won 1–0. All players in the squad played for between 45 and 75 minutes. The team then played one official friendly match, against <a href="Brazil%20Olympic%20football%20team">Brazil</a> at the <a href="Riverside%20Stadium">Riverside Stadium</a> in <a href="Middlesbrough">Middlesbrough</a> on 20 July, which was won 2–0 by Brazil.
Olympic tournament.
Great Britain's first match was a 1–1 draw with <a href="Senegal%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Senegal</a> at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a> in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a> on 26 July. <a href="Craig%20Bellamy">Craig Bellamy</a> scored for Great Britain in the first half, but Pape Moussa Konaté scored the equaliser for Senegal from a <a href="Association%20football%20tactics%20and%20skills%23Counter-attacking%20football">counter-attack</a> in the 82nd minute. Their second match was a 3–1 win against the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">United Arab Emirates</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley</a>. A <a href="Ryan%20Giggs">Ryan Giggs</a> header put Great Britain in the lead, before Ahmad Ali equalised. <a href="Scott%20Sinclair">Scott Sinclair</a> regained the lead with his first touch of the game after coming on as a substitute, and minutes later, fellow substitute <a href="Daniel%20Sturridge">Daniel Sturridge</a> chipped the UAE's goalkeeper to make it 3–1. Sturridge scored again in the 1–0 victory against <a href="Uruguay%20Olympic%20football%20team">Uruguay</a> in their final group game.
In the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament%20%E2%80%93%20Knockout%20stage">knockout stage</a>, Great Britain played <a href="South%20Korea%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">South Korea</a> in the quarterfinal round. The match went to a <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shoot-out</a> after the score was 1–1, after extra time. Great Britain lost the shoot-out 4–5 after Sturridge missed Britain's fifth attempt, while the Koreans converted all five of their attempts.
Future prospects.
During the 2012 tournament some players such as <a href="Ryan%20Giggs">Ryan Giggs</a> and some members of the British Olympic Association expressed a desire to enter a football team in future Olympics. After Great Britain's elimination from the 2012 Olympics, there were no public plans to reform the team for future Olympic Games, with Alex Horne, chief-executive of the FA, stating that the FA would not support a future men's football team at the Olympics. The problem facing any possible future Great Britain team is that there is no mechanism for it to qualify, as the individual home nations compete in the qualifying competition.
In 2015, the <a href="England%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">England under-21</a> coach (<a href="Gareth%20Southgate">Gareth Southgate</a>) and the FA Director of Elite Development (Dan Ashworth) established as FA policy that the Olympic tournament is a valuable experience for underage players. The FA subsequently advised the other home nations that they intended to enter teams in 2016, if either or both of the England teams met the qualification standard. This suggestion was opposed by the Scottish, Welsh and (Northern) Irish associations. <a href="Jim%20Boyce">Jim Boyce</a> of <a href="Irish%20Football%20Association">Northern Ireland</a>, then a vice-president of FIFA, said that he had an assurance that any future Great Britain teams would require the consent of all home nations. The FA then advised the other home nations that they would not enter teams, with the Scottish FA saying that the FA had "underestimated" opposition to the plan.
After Team GB did not enter a team at the 2016 Olympics, British Olympic Association chief executive Bill Sweeney expressed his disappointment and said talks would take place to try to field teams for the <a href="2020%20Tokyo%20Olympics">2020 Tokyo Olympics</a>. British Olympic Association vice-chairman and former sports minister <a href="Hugh%20Robertson%20%28politician%29">Sir Hugh Robertson</a> further stated: "From the British Olympic Committee's perspective, we would love to see Team GB football", whilst new <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England senior</a> team manager <a href="Sam%20Allardyce">Sam Allardyce</a> stated: "To turn it down is a great shame. It's something we may look at in the future and try to compete in." Joint talks between all four of the home nations began in September 2016. FIFA subsequently approved the idea of a Great Britain team for the 2020 games, but opposition from the Welsh, Scottish and (Northern) Irish FAs continued. FA chief executive Martin Glenn established that previous concerns over the existence of a team were no longer a concern, stating: "The big fear in the past was that if we did it we would jeopardise our independent country status. But that was sorted out under [former FIFA president Sepp] Blatter actually and <a href="Gianni%20Infantino">Gianni Infantino</a> has reinforced it." Glenn revealed that "FIFA has indicated that it's not a problem" and that "the issue is the individual interests of each home nation."
An agreement was reached between the four associations for a women's team to be entered in the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a>, with qualification depending on England's performance in the <a href="2019%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2019 World Cup</a>, but this did not affect men's football.
Colours.
The official <a href="Kit%20%28association%20football%29">kit</a> for the 2012 Olympics, designed by <a href="Stella%20McCartney">Stella McCartney</a> and manufactured by <a href="Adidas">Adidas</a>, was unveiled alongside the uniform for all Team GB Olympic competitors in March. The front of the shirt is modelled on the right-hand side of a <a href="union%20flag">union flag</a>, with the colours consisting of white and various shades of <a href="blue">blue</a> in keeping with the design of the uniforms in other sports. The back of the shirt is <a href="navy%20blue">navy blue</a>, as are the shorts and socks. The kit has a red <a href="trim%20%28sewing%29">trim</a>. The change kit is pale blue and white, with varying shades displaying the same union flag design as the home kit. The crest is on the left breast of the shirt, and consists of a white shield with the generic in blue, with the words "London 2012" below it.
Squads.
Composition.
The composition of the team has varied over time. All players in the 1908, 1912, 1920 and 1956 squads were English, while in other years players from Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales were all included. The 2012 squad contained 13 English and 5 Welsh players but no Scottish or Northern Irish players. <a href="Jack%20Butland">Jack Butland</a>, the third choice goalkeeper for England, was the only player selected for both the Olympics and the England <a href="Euro%202012">Euro 2012</a> squad. <a href="Ryan%20Giggs">Ryan Giggs</a>, <a href="Craig%20Bellamy">Craig Bellamy</a> and <a href="Micah%20Richards">Micah Richards</a> were selected as the three overage players. Former England captain <a href="David%20Beckham">David Beckham</a> was shortlisted for the Olympics, but was left out of the final squad.
London 2012 squad.
The Great Britain squad for the 2012 Olympic Games was announced on 2 July 2012, with Ryan Giggs named as captain.
